hints_html:
A probability density function integrates to \(1\).

Use partial fractions.
hints_latex: A probability density function integrates to $1$.
hints_raw:
A probability density function integrates to <math>1</math>.
Use partial fractions.
sols_html:
Notice from the definition of \(f(x)\) that if \(k < 0\) then \(f(x)\) is always 0, which cannot be a probability density function.

The same is true if \(k = 0\). Therefore we only need to consider positive values of \(k\) as candidates.

We require that

\[\begin{aligned} \int_0^{k/2} f(x) dx = 1\end{aligned}\]

Thus,

\[\begin{aligned} \int_0^{k/2} \frac{2k}{(k+x)(k-x)} dx = 1.\end{aligned}\]

To deal with the integral, we use partial fractions. We write

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{2k}{(k+x)(k-x)} = \frac{A}{k+x} + \frac{B}{k-x}.\end{aligned}\]

Now we multiply the equation through by \((k+x)(k-x)\) to find \(2k = A(k-x) + B(k+x)\).

To find \(A\) and \(B\) we can choose ``convenient" values for \(x\).

Setting \(x=k\) yields \(2k = 0 + B(k+k)\) so \(B = 1\).

Setting \(x=-k\) yields \(2k = A(k-(-k)) + 0\) so \(A = 1\).

Therefore,

\[\begin{aligned} \int_0^{k/2} f(x) dx &= \int_0^{k/2} \left(\frac{1}{k+x} + \frac{1}{k-x} \right) dx \\ &= (\ln|k+x| - \ln|k-x|)|_0^{k/2} \\ &= (\ln(3k/2) - \ln(k/2)) - (\ln k - \ln k)\\ &= \ln(3) + \ln(k) - \ln(2) - \ln(k) + \ln(2)\\ &= \ln(3)\end{aligned}\]

Note this is independent of \(k\) and it will never be \(1\). Thus no such \(k\) exist!

statement_html:
Is there any value of \(k\) for which the function \(f\) below is a probability density function?

\(f(x) = \begin{cases} \frac{2k}{(k+x)(k-x)} & \text{for } 0 \leq x \leq \frac{k}{2} \\ 0 & \text{otherwise.} \end{cases}\)

If yes, find all such values of \(k.\) If there is no such \(k\), explain why.
